snippet.title: September 2010Integrating Wikipedia and Facebook Context into Collaborative E-Brainstorming
snippet.description:
September 2010Integrating Wikipedia and Facebook Context into Collaborative E-Brainstorming
by Mike Gartrell, Aaron Beach, Jai Ramanarayanankrishnaniyer, Richard Han, Qin Lv, Shivakant Mishra, Karim Seada, Mike Gartrell, Aaron Beach, Ramanarayanankrishnaniyer Xinyu, Richard Han, Qin Lv
"... ﻿Integrating Wikipedia and Facebook Context into Collaborative E-Brainstorming Mike Gartrell 1 ..."
Abstract \- Add to MetaCart
This paper presents an application for collaborative brainstorming on shared digital displays that integrates online content to help create new ideas during the brainstorming process. The brainstorming application links ideas under discussion to their best matched Wikipedia pages, suggests related ideas for deeper discussion based on items “pinned” on the whiteboard, and recommends a broader scope of new ideas based on users ’ experiences and expertise, as derived from their social networking profiles. The software system for this application is described, including its idea recommendation engine and UI component. Experimental tests evaluating the application in the context of real users are presented.

snippet.title: Predicting tie strength with social media
snippet.description:
Predicting tie strength with social media
by Eric Gilbert, Karrie Karahalios \- In Proceedings of the Conferece on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI’09 , 2009
"... between a participant and a friend. A Facebook gift is a small icon often given to a friend to show ..."
Abstract \- Cited by 116 (2 self) \- Add to MetaCart
Social media treats all users the same: trusted friend or total stranger, with little or nothing in between. In reality, relationships fall everywhere along this spectrum, a topic social science has investigated for decades under the theme of tie strength. Our work bridges this gap between theory and practice. In this paper, we present a predictive model that maps social media data to tie strength. The model builds on a dataset of over 2,000 social media ties and performs quite well, distinguishing between strong and weak ties with over 85 % accuracy. We complement these quantitative findings with interviews that unpack the relationships we could not predict. The paper concludes by illustrating how modeling tie strength can improve social media design elements, including privacy controls, message routing, friend introductions and information prioritization. Author Keywords Social media, social networks, relationship modeling, ties,

snippet.title: Exploration and Field Study of a Browser-based Password Manager using Icon-based Passwords
snippet.description:
Exploration and Field Study of a Browser-based Password Manager using Icon-based Passwords
by Kemal Bicakci, Nart Bedin Atalay, Mustafa Yuceel, Paul C. van Oorschot , 2011
"... ﻿Exploration and Field Study of a Browser-based Password Manager using Icon-based Passwords ⋆ Kemal ..."
Abstract \- Cited by 1 (0 self) \- Add to MetaCart
We carry out a hybrid lab and field study of a password manager program, and report on usability and security. Our study explores iPMAN, a browser-based password manager that in addition uses a graphical password scheme for the master password. We present our findings as a set of observations and insights expected to be of interest both to those exploring password managers, and graphical passwords. Motivated by our findings, but also of independent interest, we also present a new salt generation method using blind signatures, to protect against offline attacks, decreasing user inconvenience by generating salt significantly faster than earlier work (Halderman et al. 2005).
